dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red frizzy hair flies across our screen in slow motion. Glimpses of tinsel, and a transparent peignoir momentaril hide a large pair of sagging breasts swinging from side t side and bouncing up and down. Dead silence as the moveme gradually speeds up to real time. We slowly pull back to reveal that our image is that of a giant nude woman dress in nothing but tiny bits of glitter, white vinyl boots an small tulle cape. She is gyrating madly and flinging her around in some sort of windstorm. As we pull back further come to understand that what we are looking at is an art installation: a floor to ceiling LCD screen. The sound of breathing. A close up of a woman’s eyes now fills our screen. SUSAN MORROW, 42, handsome. Sleek. Ther a very slight hint of panic on her face as she stares acr the crowded, brightly lit room. Abruptly our sound snaps on at a deafening decibel level we hear what seems like a thousand voices screaming over other. The screens cover the four walls of the gallery and the effect of wall to wall, floor to ceiling breast and ass jiggling is oddly impressive. The obese women on the LCD screens are nude but dressed in bits and pieces of Americ one is playing the part of a cheerleader with red tinsel poms, one a majorette twirling a baton while another wear beauty queen’s ribbon and waves small American flags. The taunt us and tease us. On raised plinths scattered around the room are incredibl life like sculptures of seemingly the same corpulent wome our video screens. These women appear to be dead and are lying face down. Nude except for jewelry, shoes and small bits of tinsel wrapped around their ankles and waists. The room is jammed with people laughing and talking. The crowd is a collection of what passes in contemporary Los Angeles culture as the chic and fashionable. Photographer track several of the guests as the flash of their cameras heightens the excitement in the room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MORROW GALLERY, LOS ANGELES. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Silence. The gallery is now empty. A small crew of men in white shirts and dark ties clear away the last traces of party. Susan is sitting on one of the plinths deep in thought. A nude sculpture lying face down is behind her. women on the screens continue to gyrate on all four walls

dialogues.speaker: -- LATER.
dialogues.text: Susan’s car weaves it’s way through the night.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MORROW RESIDENCE, LOS ANGELES. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Susan pulls up to a pair of large stainless steel gates. glare of her headlights reflects off of the gates and temporarily blinds her as she shields her eyes. She hits remote and the massive gates glide open. She drives in as gates close behind her. As the gates lock in place, another car pulls into the driveway. The glare of the headlights blinds us so that w cannot make out anything but the silhouette of the driver see clearly however from the large logo on the hubcap tha the car is a vintage dark brown Mercedes. The car door op as the driver lowers his foot onto the gravel drive. We cut back to the house to see Susan’s silhouette as she walks towards the front door. The house is dimly lit and seemingly empty.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MORROW RESIDENCE, LOS ANGELES. MORNING
dialogues.text: Our camera glides across the surface of a black swimming littered with leaves. We pull back to reveal a vast unkem lawn and a large Jeff Koons “Balloon Dog” sculpture on a plinth. There are tools, equipment and a small crane next the sculpture. Despite the neglected feeling of the groun the house is impressive. Long, low, and elegant.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MORROW RESIDENCE, LOS ANGELES. MORNING
dialogues.text: We move into the living room which is an expanse of grey carpet and low velvet sofas. There are several very large crates lining the hall. The house is beautiful but cold a empty. Our camera moves down a long corridor towards a door at t end. The hallway seems endless. A large white Calder mobi moves slowly over a fireplace at the end of the hall as t breeze from the air-conditioner stirs it. Susan stands underneath the Calder in front of an enormou television with a remote control in her hand. Pressing it over and over. As we approach the door the sound of the television becom louder and louder. We can hear two women’s voices as they shriek with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION VOICE 1
dialogues.text: And all that decolletage of yours should get you more dickoletage than that dude’s got! And as I can recall, you were the one that told me that when he came it was as thin as coconut water! Honey, that’s a deal breaker for me!

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION VOICE 2
dialogues.text: It was that thin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I see we're settling for less now! The women break into hysterical laughter once again. We cut to Susan’s face. Her mouth literally hangs open as stands staring at the television and holding the remote i her hand trying to get the television to turn off.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Beyond. She tosses the remote on the bed in disgust and walks out the room leaving the television still on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTOPHER, 38, wearing a dark suit and tie is placing t mail on a small desk.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Morrow, a package arrived for you. I found it in the mailbox this morning. May I ask you who you would like on duty this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Actually, why don’t you give everyone the weekend off.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes. We might go to the beach house and if not it might be nice to have the weekend alone.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I’1ll let everyone know.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. Susan stares at the package for a moment. It is a simple wrapped in plain brown paper. Susan begins to rip the wrapping off of the box. As she d she cuts her finger on the edge of the paper.  She winces, looks at the blood and then quickly puts her finger in her mouth. SUSAN (CONT’D) Damn it. Christopher, I’m sorry but could you help me open this? I just cut my finger. Paper cut.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. Christopher rips the paper off of the package. Inside is neat grey linen archival box and a hand written note.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: There’s a note.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It’s okay. You can read it. Christopher reads the note aloud.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Dear Susan, I've written a novel that will be published in the spring. It’s different than the kind of things that I was writing when we were together. Christopher pauses and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: In the end you left me with the inspiration that I needed to write from the heart. I wanted you to be the first to read it so I am sending along a proof. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will be in LA until Wednesday on business and it would be good to see you after so long. My cell number and e-mail address are below. Edward. Susan stands stunned for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Thanks. Christopher places the note back on the box and leaves th room. Susan’s gaze is transfixed as she stares down at th note. She picks up the box and carries it into the kitchen. INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - KITCHEN. MORNING -- CONTINUOUS. HUTTON MORROW, 44 years old, tall, athletic and well groo dressed in a crisp white button down shirt, blue blazer a grey pants, enters the room. Hutton’s face gives away the fact that he has not slept. Susan is washing the cut on her finger at the sink.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It’s a manuscript that Edward sent me. He wrote a novel.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: Edward who?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Edward, my first husband. Remember him?  Hutton is

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: I didn’t know he could write.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes you did. He was writing a novel when you and got together, you just don’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: Have you even talked to him in 20 years?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: 19. No. I tried calling hima couple of times a few years ago but he just hung up on me. I think he’s teaching English at some prep school in Dallas. It’s sad really. He never remarried. not really listening. He is putting a Nespresso pod into the coffee machine. She turns SUSAN (CONT’D) Where were you last night? You didn’t come by the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Really. By the time I left the office I was late for my dinner...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It would have taken you 15 minutes. 15 minutes and it would have meant a lot to me. (Pause) Never mind. away from him. SUSAN (CONT’D) You didn’t come to bed last night.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to wake you up.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Well, I wasn’t asleep. I was too wound up from the opening.  Hutton tosses his newspaper on the counter and begins to read. SUSAN (CONT’D) It went well by the way. Apparently.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: Good. Susan crosses the room to Hutton.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Look. Why don’t you and I go to the beach. We can go tonight and come back on Monday. Maybe if we just spent some time, just the two of us... Susan glances up at him. SUSAN (CONT’D) Why are you wearing this blazer on a Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: Because I have to go to the office and then I have to go to the airport and then I have to go back to New York.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You just came from there.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. But I have to go if I want to get this deal done. I don’t want to have to sell anything else. Hutton is ripping a packet of sweetener open and he spill on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: shit. Susan begins sweeping it away.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It’s okay.  11 12 Susan looks at crate in the hall. SUSAN (CONT’D) You know, the strange thing is that I don’t really care about all of this art.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: That doesn’t sound like you.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I know. But it’s true.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: I care. It pisses me off.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I know you do. She pauses a moment. SUSAN (CONT’D) Don’t worry, I can fill the walls with some new LA artists and people will think we’re ahead of the curve instead of going broke. You won't have to be embarrassed. Hutton glares at her as she walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Hutton get out of their car. A black vintage Bentley coupe. There are several impressive and flashy ca parked in front of the door.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS.
dialogues.text: We enter the house. It is beautiful and expensive. The ar the walls is staggering and the mix of contemporary art w 18th century furniture and the modern architecture of the house itself is eccentric in the extreme. A butler leads into a room filled with a small group of people. All know each other well. Susan and Hutton are greeted with cheek kisses.  10. Susan stands talking with ALESSIA HOLT, 38, dressed in a kaftan and covered in gold and turquoise jewelry. She is tall, pale and her eyes are darkened with heavy liner and even heavier shadow so that she almost has the appearance a raccoon. She moves her hands wildly when she speaks. Sh flamboyant but there is a kindness and gentle quality abo her. The two women are clearly close as is evident by the easy rapport.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSIA
dialogues.text: Are things a little better?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: He’s just having a hard time with his business right now. They glance across the room at Hutton who is speaking wit CARLOS HOLT early 50's, silver hair, tall and elegant.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSIA
dialogues.text: Carlos told me.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I’m surprised. I thought we were hiding it pretty well. Hutton would be very upset to find out that anyone knew. He just hates not to win. She looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSIA
dialogues.text: Are you sleeping? Did you call my psychopharmacologist? She takes a sip of her martini.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you call him? You should because he’s a genius. Hutton has pulled away from Carlos and stepped into the h He is on his phone. Susan watches him. Alessia reaches out and touches Susan’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Susan, I’m worried about you.  11. Susan is focused on Hutton who is still on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seriously, look at me. You scared me the last time that we talked. She looks at Alessia and her shoulders droop. She feels comfortable enough with Alessia to let a certain fragilit show.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I’m fine. I just can’t believe I told you all of those things. I feel embarrassed about it. What right do I have to not be happy? I have everything. I feel ungrateful not to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSIA
dialogues.text: As much right as anyone Susan. As much right as anyone because it’s all relative. You’re just awfully hard on yourself. Susan looks across the room at Carlos.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: How do you do it?

dialogues.speaker: ALESSIA
dialogues.text: You mean with Carlos? I’m totally cool with it. Having a gay husband is not such a bad thing. We’re best friends. We love each other completely. I’m certainly the only woman in his life. And that lasts longer than lust doesn’t it? It’s forever really. Alessia glances towards Hutton.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Hutton and I don’t have that.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSIA
dialogues.text: Did you ever?  13 14 12.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I think we just want different things. Or maybe I want different things.

dialogues.speaker: ALESSIA
dialogues.text: Do you still love him? She looks up and Hutton catches her eyes and motions to h with his head.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'm being summoned. Pardon me. He has to catch a plane. I need to say goodbye. Susan crosses the room to Hutton and leads him to the doo Alessia stares after her.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS.
dialogues.text: We are on the front steps of the house. There is a black Mercedes and driver waiting for Hutton.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I hope that this deal works out for you. I really do. I know that you need it.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: We need this.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No, you need this. She leans in to kiss him on the cheek. She watches the ca pull out of the driveway and goes back into the house. INT. HOLT RESIDENCE, BEL AIR CALIFORNIA. NIGHT -- LATER. The flamboyant and eclectic guests are seated around the dining table finishing dessert. Conversation at the table lively, and somewhat loud. Susan is seated next to Carlos  13. At that moment the other end of the table erupts with laughter as CHLOE, 24, a beautiful young actress finishes story. She speaks with a strong southern accent and has a certain vapid charm. The table is riveted.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: So I said, “well my mother always told me if you massage your pussy with Pam Cooking Spray for a month before the baby comes you won’t need vaginal rejuvenation!” The table burst into hysterical laughter. Susan turns bac Carlos.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I’ve got to get some Pam. And she is going to get a nomination this year.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: A nomination? She is going to win! They both look towards Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s talk about your opening. My favorite subject.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Not mine.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: The opening was spectacular last night.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Really? Is that what you thought?

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: You didn’t?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: I loved it. I thought the work was incredibly strong. So perfect with all of this junk culture that we live in.  15 16 14.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It is junk. Total junk.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Darling, you’re a big success. None of us really like what we do.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: So why do we do it?

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Because we are driven. And maybe a bit insecure. We get into things when we’re young because we think they mean something.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: And then we find out that they don’t.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Susan, enjoy the absurdity of our world. It’s a lot less painful. And believe me, our world is a lot less painful than the real world. INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BATHROOM. NIGHT -- LATER. Susan is dressed for bed. She looks in the mirror for a moment. She opens her medicine cabinet and takes two different pills. INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BEDROOM. NIGHT -- MINUTES LATER. One wall of the room is all glass. The view across the la and down to the city is dramatic and eerie at the same ti As Susan sits down on the bed, her eyes catch the cover o “Nocturnal Animals” on her bedside table. She pauses, the picks up the manuscript and opens it to the first page. She is momentarily taken aback by the dedication. The cle white page reads simply: “For Susan”. She begins to read...  17 15. EXT. HASTINGS RESIDENCE, HOUSTON TEXAS. PRESENT DAY -—— 1 DUSK. We are in the driveway of a modest but well designed ranc styled house. A large oak tree looms over the lawn and th sound of cicadas can be heard. TONY HASTINGS, early 40s, dark brown hair with a full bea is loading bags into the back of a vintage 4 door brown Mercedes. He is dressed in jeans and a red plaid shirt. I HASTINGS, 16, is helping him. She is tall and slim with l red hair.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: Dad, why are we driving this old thing to Marfa?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Because I just had it completely rebuilt. It’s a classic.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: It has a terrible sound system. She throws a bag in the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Well you’ll have to suffer through that. He lifts a pair of riding boots into the back of the car.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have two sets of boots India?

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: Do we really have to stop tonight? I'd rather just get there.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Ask your mother. She’s the boss. LAURA HASTINGS, 40, shoulder length red hair, slim and pr like her daughter, comes out of the house with a small ba She gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I set the alarm.  18 19 16. The car pulls out of the driveway and into the twilight. Driving out of the sprawl that is Houston and into the country, until the highway stretches out straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HASTINGS CAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: India is texting in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: India, you have been doing that for hours. I thought you were the one who wanted to drive all night.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: I did. But what are we supposed to do, sing campfire songs or something? The road is even more flat and straight now. The highway increasingly deserted and has narrowed to two lanes on ea side. Every few minutes a car passes them in the left lan the headlights of an oncoming car can be seen across the median.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: How much longer?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: About three and a half hours.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: Well dad, you’re going to get your wish. My cell service just went out. Jesus, can you believe that there is no service here? How is that even be possible?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Two of the things I love most about west Texas; no phones and no people.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HASTINGS CAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Silence in the car. Tony is driving and Laura and India a asleep. Tony is fumbling to find a radio station but none within range.  17. Tony looks over at Laura and touches her cheek. She opens eyes for a moment, smiles at him and kisses his hand. Straight ahead on the highway, Tony sees two sets of tail lights blocking both lanes of the road. Tony has to slow speed and he gets behind the car on the left and waits. B cars are now slowing down even more.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Come on. Tony presses his horn lightly. Laura and India wake up. T car in the left lane, an old dark green metallic Pontiac with a dented fender finally pulls ahead and Tony follows zooms past the first car, an old dark red Cadillac convertible, and gets back into the right lane as the gre GTO speeds off into the distance. The Cadillac falls behi The GTO in front now begins to slow down as well. As Tony passes the car the driver leans back into his seat and laughs. There are two other men in the car but we cannot their faces.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: Total Jerks.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Are we rid of them? India gives them the finger from the rear window.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: India, don’t do that!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What? What did she do?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She just gave them the finger. The driver of the green GTO now steps on the gas and begi to gain on Tony.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tony! Speed up.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: Shit!  18.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No. I don’t like this.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It’s alright.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Just speed up. Tony! The dark green GTO is now honking and roars up beside the family.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Just let them go. Let them go. The three men in the car are staring at the family and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: India, don’t look at them. Don’t give them any reason. The man in the passenger side of the car is looking at In with a lascivious grin on his face. The other men in the are laughing.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: Why is he smiling like that? Suddenly the green GTO lunges sideways towards Tony’s car forcing him to swerve. The GTO then pulls in front of the Mercedes and cuts them off.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: He's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh my god. Tony pulls out to pass the car but as he does the car in front swings left to block his way and Tony hits his brak As Tony swerves back to the right the GTO cuts him off ag preventing him from passing. In a surge of rage Tony step the gas. A loud metallic crashing noise. He hits them.  19.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Fuck. Tony, shocked at what has just happened steps on the gas, gets around the other car. As he passes the GTO the drive waving madly and screaming at him to pull over and stop.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh god, Tony. The lights of the GTO grow distant as Tony speeds away. T car is quiet as the family sit stunned at what just happe

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: India, is your phone working yet?

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: No, but I took down their license number. As Tony checks his rear view mirror he sees a pair of headlights beginning to gain on him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No. Laura looks in the side view mirror and sees the car approaching.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh no. The GTO now roars up beside them on the left and the guy the passenger seat is waving his arms violently at them, shouting, shaking his fist and pointing. The car swerves towards them and tries to force Tony onto the shoulder. T keeps his foot on the peddle and keeps his hands gripped firmly on the steering wheel. The green GTO suddenly rams into the Mercedes, pulls back then rams them again and again forcing Tony to move towar the shoulder of the road as he begins to loose control of car. Another crashing sound against his left fender and he fee the damage. The GTO pushes against him continuously and h steady. The loud raw grating noise of metal ripping at me is deafening.  20 21 20. Tony's steering wheel begins to rattle and shake as the o car forces him off of the road and lands in front of him cloud of dust and gravel. INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BEDROOM. NIGHT -- 20 CONTINUOUS. Shaken by what she has just read, Susan tries to catch he breath. She turns the page...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HIGHWAY, WEST TEXAS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: As the dust settles as we can see clearly that the Hastin car is blocked in by the other car. Laura looks back to m sure that India is okay as the second car, the convertibl that was lagging behind, comes into sight. We see the wid grin of the shirtless driver as the car slows and then sp away. The family sits in shock trying to figure out what to do. The driver's side of the old Buick opens and a man, RAY MARCUS late 20s, rough looking yet surprisingly handsome, steps out. Laura reaches for Tony’s arm. The other men in car are looking on but we do not make out their faces clearly.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Sit still. They’ve probably got a gun.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Please Tony. Pull out.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I can’t move. He’s blocked the car. The man walks around to the back of his car to survey the damage. He begins to talk to the man in the front passeng seat.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s he doing? He then walks over to Tony’s car. Slowly. He is wearing a western shirt, jeans and bright green cowboy boots. He lo at the front of Tony’s car and comes to the window.  21.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Don’t get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m not getting out of the car sweetheart. Ray motions for Tony to roll down his window. Tony does t reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Good evenin. Ray smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to stop when there is an accident.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Then why didn’t you stop then? The man leans down and looks inside the car at Laura and India. India is trying to get a signal with her phone aga

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: After the way you were driving?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Laura...

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What did you say?  22. Ray’s hand is resting on top of the Mercedes. He is tappi his fingers on the roof of the car over and over. We can clearly the twinkle of a pink diamond heart shaped girl’s ring on his little finger. His dirty nails are long and t of someone who plays the guitar. He has the swagger of a seventies rock star.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Just that the way you were driving was crazy. Ray bangs his hand on the roof of the car and spits.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Hey Turk! The doors on the right side of the Buick open and the two get out. TURK who is the smallest of the three and LOU wh tall and thin with a dead look in his eyes. Both men wear baseball hats.

dialogues.text: Ray puts his hands on the half opened window and leans in

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Lady, lady, lady... Calm down. We got an accident to report, that’s all. One of the men shines his flashlight at Laura.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Leave us alone.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It’s just a flashlight sweetheart. It’s just a flashlight. It’s alright.  23.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. The other two men are inspecting the front of Tony’s car putting their hands on the hood and leaning down under th car. We cannot see what they are doing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Okay. All right. Let’s exchange information.

dialogues.speaker: RAY

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Alright. Open up the glove compartment sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Let's exchange information. Okay. I'm a Gemini, my favorite color is petal pink, and I like long walks and kittens. Ray breaks into hysterical laughter as he claws with his nails at the window imitating a kitten. The family sits dumbstruck, as the other men laugh along with Ray.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know what, we should call the police.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Oh? It’s a great idea. It was your fuckin fault, right?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter whose fault it was Tony. The two men in front walk around to the side of the car.  24.

dialogues.speaker: TURK
dialogues.text: Hey Ray, this guy’s got a flat tire.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh come on! Ray goes around to look. The men all start to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Well what do you know? Well sure thing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What? Someone kicks the tire and the car rocks a bit.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: Don't believe it, dad. The three men come to the driver’s window.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Yep. Your left tire is flat, sure is.

dialogues.speaker: TURK

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You must have busted it when you was shoving us off the road. Someone cackles.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Shhh. Be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: (Quietly) It’s a lie.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You think I’m a liar?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: She's just a child.  25.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You think I’m a liar!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No. She’s not saying that man. She's just a child. He waves the other guys back.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You don’t got a flat, go on and drive. Start the engine and drive. Drive on it asshole, drive away. Nobody's stopping you. Tony starts the car and rolls it forward. It is evident t the tire is flat. He turns off the engine.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: God damn it!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh god! Oh god! What are we going to do Tony? What are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It’s alright. It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Tell you what. We’ll fix it for you. Won’t we, guys?

dialogues.speaker: TURK
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Yeah, just to show you we're okay we'll fix it for you, you won't have to do a thing, and then we’1l go to the cops together, you and me, and report your accident.  26.

dialogues.speaker: TURK
dialogues.text: You got tools, mister?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Don’t get out of the car. Please.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: No need. Use ours. Come on, let’s get going. The three men go to the trunk of their car while Tony and wife and daughter watch with their doors locked. They wat while the men bring out their tools, the jack, the tire i

dialogues.speaker: TURK
dialogues.text: You got a spare tire man? Tony pauses. He is not sure. The men start to laugh. All Ray who is lighting a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You cain’t change a tire without a spare.

dialogues.speaker: TURK
dialogues.text: You wanna give me the keys to the trunk?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: No, dad. Turk looks at India for a long time. Staring. Looking her and down.

dialogues.speaker: TURK
dialogues.text: Who the fuck do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Just pop the trunk open for me Laura. Tony gets out of the car and lifts out the suitcases and boxes in the light of the flashlight held by Turk, until get at the spare tire.  27. Ray taking a drag off of his cigarette begins dancing nex the car.

dialogues.speaker: TURK
dialogues.text: Get the women outta the car.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Come on, get em out. Tony stares blankly at Ray as he weighs this in his mind. is becoming irritated.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on man! We gotta lift your car up on a jack so get um out. Tony looks around surveying the situation.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dude! We gotta lift your wife and your child and your car? Get your women out of the car! Tony looks at his wife and daughter. He clocks the man wi the crowbar and the other with the wrench.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It’s all right honey. They just want you out while they fix the tire. Laura and India get out and stand near the door of the ca The men begin raising the car and loosening the flat tire Ray is kicking the luggage around at the back of the car inspecting it with the toe of his cowboy boot. He looks u Tony.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Come over here. Tony walks towards him . RAY (CONT’D) You seen what you did to my car? You think you’re fuckin hot shit don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  28.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: They definitely think they’re fuckin hot shit.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Are you serious. Your bitches man, who else? You too. You think you're somthin special, you can bump a guy’s car and then leave the scene of an accident.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Listen, you were playing some kind of crazy game with us on the road.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Yeah? The flashing blue lights of a police car suddenly appear. car is moving at very high speed, clearly on a call. Tony steps towards the road and waves his arms. Laura and Indi run towards the road screaming. They are too late and sho frantically into the night as the police car speeds off i the distance. Ray holds his breath for a moment and then and the other two men start laughing.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There goes your cops. You should have tried harder to stop them. But that’s okay. We’ll take good care of you. The men continue to work on the car. They seem to enjoy i and laugh and talk. Ray is not laughing. Ray paces back and forth while the other two men finish changing the tire. Ray looks periodically over at Laura a India tapping his feet and murmuring under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Murmuring) Fuckin bitches. Fuckin god damned uppity bitches. Fuck you. I’1l teach you a thing or two. Fuck you...  29. Tony is watching Ray pace back and forth. He hears what h saying. RAY (CONT’D) What are you looking at? Hot shot. He is muttering to himself and becoming more agitated. RAY (CONT’D) What were you trying to do there on the road?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: We are just trying to get to where we are going.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: And where’s that? Tony says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I said, where are you going.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Marfa.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: And what exactly is in Marfa? Tony looks at the ground. The man moves closer to Tony an brings his face level with his. Tony takes a step backwar and Ray closes the gap. Ray leans forward forcing Tony to lean back.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I said, what’s in Marfa? Hey mother fucker. Ray takes hold of Tony’s crotch and shoves him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey, let go of me.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: Leave my dad alone, asshole!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: India...  30.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Fuck you, baby.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She didn't mean that. She’s just a kid. Ray strolls over to where India and Laura are standing. T are terrified. Turk grabs Tony and pushes him backwards as Ray shoves In up against the car.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What’s in Marfa? Your daddy won't tell me so why don’t you.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: What is it to you anyway? Tony is now fighting to get to India as Turk pushes him b with a crowbar.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Come on baby, we're nice guys. We're fixin your tire. Ray begins to dance in front of India, trapping her at th door of the car.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wanna dance? Wanna dance? Ray looks towards Tony who is still struggling with Turk get towards his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Let her go!

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Look at him. Your daddy thinks he’s so much better than me. What do you think? India looks him straight in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: Well he is.  31.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Look at him. He’s a wimp. A total pussy.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Get your hands off of her!

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: You’re scum, you know. Ray takes a step towards India. Laura steps in between bu pushes her aside. He puts his hands on the girl’s shoulde Instantly Laura is on him hitting and kicking and pulling him from behind until she is flung to the side.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Bitch! Tony moves in but before he knows it Ray knocks him back. Tony falls to the ground. His nose is bleeding. Ray faces three of them.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Watch it you fucking assholes. You got no fucking right to talk to me like that! The men by the tire stop to watch.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Christ sake, we're fixin your god damned tire! He walks around to the other two men. Laura wraps her arm around India and tries to calm her down. Tony struggles t get up from the pavement, his nose bleeding profusely.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (To Tony) You all right over there? Need a tissue? Ray walks over to Tony who is now standing holding onto h nose as the blood runs down his face.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God damn! That looks bad! He turns towards Laura and India.  32.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey honey! You got a tampon? Your nose looks like shit!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I mean it looks like shit.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m fine. The men have finished with the car. Ray looks over at the

dialogues.text: Are we good? We’re good. We’re set. We're good to go.

dialogues.text: Alright. How far up the road until we can get a phone signal?

dialogues.text: And why do you want to get further up the road? So you can leave the scene of an accident again? Ray moves closer to Tony.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: Leave him alone! Ray looks over at India and stares at her for a moment. H then turns back to Tony.

dialogues.text: There’s service up by Bailey. How do you think we’re gonna get there though?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: In our cars.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Which car?  33.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Both cars.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Naw, mister. Don’t try no fuckin shit with me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You heard me. I know what you’re doin. I know what your plan is.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What is the matter?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Don’t try no fucking shit with me.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What is the matter? What the fuck is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: How do I know that you ain’t gonna just floor the gas and leave me in the dust.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Alright fine. Get in your car and we'll follow you there.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Fuck you! No way! You go in my car.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No. No way.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You come with us.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No. I’m not going to do that.  34.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Okay fine. You drive your car and the girl comes with us. Ray starts to move around the back of the car towards Lau and India. Lou moves towards Tony to hold him back. Laura tries to push Ray away from India but is blocked by Turk throws her to the ground. Ray picks India up and begins t carry her to the front of the car. The two women begin screaming as the situation becomes more violent. Tony fin breaks free from Lou and moves in towards the car only to held back once again.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Stop! What are you doing! Stop! Get your hands off of them! India breaks free and runs down the road as Ray stands catching his breath. He calls after her as he rubs his crotch.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Bye bye sweetheart. I love you!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: India! Laura is still struggling with Turk as Lou releases Tony.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get your hands off of her! Laura breaks free and runs towards India. Ray looks towar Tony who is now slowly wandering down the road towards La and India. He is dazed.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Look what you gone and did! He looks towards Laura.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is she the boss? Is she the boss of your family?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Laura!  35. As Tony moves towards his wife and daughter Ray follows a drops down to his knees in front of Tony.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Have you got a vagina? Have you got a fuckin vagina there? Ray flattens himself on the road and begins fucking the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, vagina boy! Vagina boy! Tony finally snaps, moves quickly to Ray and screams at t top of his voice.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Stay away! Stay away! Stay the fuck away! Ray is now right in Tony’s face as the two men stand screaming at each other. Laura runs to the car and shouts Tony and India to get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Tony! Tony! Get in the car! There is a rush of motion, the men are startled, India ru to the car and makes her way around to the rear door and the backseat, slamming and locking the door behind her. L also jumps into the front seat and locks the door. Ray has now moved away from Tony and towards the Mercedes

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Hey! Here we go! Go in both cars! Hey Lou! Ray runs around to the driver's side of the Mercedes and starts to jump in just before Laura realizes too late wha happening and is not able to reach across and lock the do He braces the door open with his foot as Laura scratches claws at him as he tries to get in. As Tony looks up, he sees Turk reach around and unlock th back door as India bites him and screams. He fights her o and pushes his way into the car as Ray slams the driver's door and starts the car.  22 23 36.

dialogues.speaker: INDIA
dialogues.text: Dad! Dad! Tony stares at what is happening in complete disbelief. H freezes and stands for a moment paralyzed. India’s scream pierces the silence of the night and finally pulls him ba to reality. He snaps to and moves towards the car but immediately Lou is upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a violent roar the car pulls onto the highway and sp away.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No! No! Tony sees the horrified faces of his wife and daughter as car rushes away. India’s tear streaked face staring back him from the rear window. The sound of the car fades and red tail lights grow fainter and then disappear all toget

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No! No! No! INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BEDROOM. NIGHT -- 22 CONTINUOUS. Horrified, Susan snaps the book closed. She is stunned. T deafening silence and the stillness of her bedroom is in sharp contrast to the scene she just read. It takes her a moment to calm down. She picks up her phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL, NEW YORK. EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Hutton is in the lobby of the hotel. His cell phone buzze He looks at it and answers.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: Susan?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you call to let me know that you got in safely.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to wake you. It’s 4 o'clock in the morning there. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why are you still up? Take one of those pills.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: Walking in the door of the hotel. We see that Hutton is not alone. He is with a beautiful w in her early 30s. Very much like a younger version of Sus Hutton puts his hand up to his lips to signify to her tha she should not speak. They step into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR OPERATOR
dialogues.text: What floor sir?

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: 31 please. Susan overhears this.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: That’s not our usual floor.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: Our regular room wasn't available. You should have seen the scene that I caused in the lobby. Susan softens.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I hope you got some sleep on the plane. I do worry about you, even though you think I don’t. You must be exhausted. I hate that flight. It’s too short to really...

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR OPERATOR
dialogues.text: 31, Madam. 24 INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BEDROOM. NIGHT -- 24 CONTINUOUS. Susan clocks the “Madam”.  25 38.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: At my floor. Got to go. I’1l call you later. Long pause as we watch Susan’s face.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Susan? Susan does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Susan? Can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes. I heard you. Get some sleep. She hangs up the phone. Susan sits staring into space, on the edge of her bed. Sh closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Lou run towards the GTO as the dust still linger from the other car.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: You drive. Tony gets into the dark green car. Lou sits next to him o the passenger side. Tony starts the car as quickly as he and speeds off after the Mercedes. He reaches an exit.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Is this the exit?

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: The exit for what?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: For Bailey?

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Keep going.  39. The car bounces off of the pavement on to a dirt road. As they round a corner they pass an old abandoned adobe chur Tony slows the car.

dialogues.speaker: LOU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep going. Speed up. They pass through a chain link gate onto an even less traveled road.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing to us?

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Here. Turn down here. Tony stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Look, fuck you. I’m not going down that road!

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Listen mister. You wanna see your wife and kid? Then turn down that road. Tony hangs his head.

dialogues.speaker: LOU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You gonna cry now? Tony slowly raises his head, and steps on the gas. As the car makes the turn the lights illuminate the brush for ju an instant. There is an old trailer off of the side of th road. A dark colored car is parked in a turnout next to t trailer, partially hidden behind a cluster of mesquite tr

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: But that’s my car we just passed!

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: It ain’t your car man. Keep goin. Tony continues to drive.

dialogues.speaker: LOU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t think you need to worry about your wife and kid. Like I say you don’t need to worry about them.  40.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What do you mean I don’t need to worry about them? What the fuck does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Calm down. He ain’t never killed nobody yet. That’s all I mean. At least as far as I know he ain't.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Killed! Why are you talking about killing!

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: I said he AIN'T killed nobody yet. His voice is very quiet.

dialogues.speaker: LOU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you’d listen to me you would hear what I was saying. They come to a clearing were the tracks disappear into th grass. The site is littered with beer bottles and a few shotgun cartridges. Tony comes to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: LOU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, looks like we run outta road. They ain’t here. Wonder if I made a mistake. It’s time for you to get out now okay? Before he knows it, Lou jumps out of the door, comes arou to Tony’s side of the car and flings the door open.

dialogues.speaker: GET OUT
dialogues.text: Lou grabs Tony by the arm, yanks hard and in one motion throws him on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: LOU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll get killed if you don’t watch it. He gets into the car, slams the door, jerks forward, and starts back up the deserted road. Tony chases after the c and bangs on the door as Lou kicks the dust up in Tony’s face.  26 41. Tony watches the red lights disappear. Except for the lig of the vast sky and the sound of coyotes in the distance night is completely black. Tony sits down on the ground and starts to cry. He pounds fists into his legs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DESERT, WEST TEXAS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tony hears a faint but steady whooshing sound in the distance, and then the far away cry of what could be the of a large truck. The sounds come from the opposite direc of the dirt road. Tony stands up, thinks and starts walki in the direction of the sound. As he does we see lights coming along down the dirt road. car stops at the clearing where Tony was kicked out. Two get out. Although it is not completely clear, the car loo like Tony’s Mercedes. Tony sees the beam of a flashlight and flattens himself reflexively behind a large boulder and a clump of brush a the edge of the arroyo.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What did you fuckin leave him out here for?

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Hey mister! Your wife wants you! Tony holds still.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Get back in the fuckin car.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Mister? Your wife wants you. Silence. Footsteps in the brush very close by.

dialogues.speaker: LOU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mister! Ah Shit! The men get back in the car and slam the doors. The light the car illuminate the top of the grass and brush like a movie stage. After a moment the car turns back down the d road.  27 28 29 30 42. Tony stays flat against the ground. Silence. The sounds o the desert. In the distance the whooshing sound seems lou than before. Tony pulls himself up and starts walking towards the soun As Tony walks through the desert brush the sky begins to lighten a bit to a deep violet. Tony climbs down an arroyo and crawls under a barbed wire fence. As he does he falls to the ground and twists his ankle. The sky is beginning to turn a light pink.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HIGHWAY, WEST TEXAS. DAWN
dialogues.text: Tony wanders along the highway signaling and waving his a to get someone to stop but no one does. He keeps walking puts his arm out as every car passes. Screaming at times cars to stop. Finally, on the side of the road, Tony sees small adobe house. He rushes up to the door and begins banging on the door furiously. A woman in shorts answers. hear a baby crying in the background.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: May I use your phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony sits in a glassed in room starring into space. INT. MORROW RESIDENCE SUSAN’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. 29 Susan lies on her bed deep in thought. She is holding ont small gold cross around her neck. “Nocturnal Animals” lie next to her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. POLICE STATION, WEST TEXAS. MORNING
dialogues.text: LIEUTENANT GRAVES, heavy set, 60s, asks Tony questions.  31 32 33 34 35 43.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GRAVES
dialogues.text: Mr. Hastings, there is no town near here called “Bailey”.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I was afraid of that. Tony, bleary eyed, stares off in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GRAVES
dialogues.text: There’s a motel across the street. Have you got any money?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I have credit cards.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GRAVES
dialogues.text: It’s still early Mr. Hastings. We'll call if we get anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neon sign in front of the motel flicks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony is attempting to lie comfortably in the tiny tub of motel room. He is washing the blood and dirt off of his f The steam from the water rises. The light is a harsh glow The tub is dingy with green tiles and a plastic shower curtain. He begins to cry softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan lies in her tub with her eyes open. Thinking. There only a dim light in the room coming from the open door. INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BEDROOM. EARLY MORNING. 3 Susan lies on her bed motionless, staring at the ceiling. is another grey foggy LA day. INT. MOTEL, WEST TEXAS. TONY’S ROOM. DAY. 35 Tony lies on the bed sprawled out with his shirt off. His hair is wet. The air conditioner is on full blast.  36
The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GRAVES
dialogues.text: This is Lieutenant Graves. They found your car over in a washed out arroyo at Topping.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What about my wife and daughter?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GRAVES
dialogues.text: Still no news. They weren’t in the car. Tony flinches.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GRAVES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're turning this case over to Lieutenant Andes. Can he pick you up in a few minutes?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m ready now.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOTEL PARKING LOT, WEST TEXAS. DAY
dialogues.text: A police car sits in front of the motel office. A tall sl man in a western jacket and a cowboy hat is standing at t back of the car smoking. This is BOBBY ANDES, late 40s, weathered face, faded brown hair, with a mustache. He is imposing.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Glad to meetcha. I’m Bobby Andes. I look into things around here.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You found my car?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: They found it in a creek bed. He takes a drag of his cigarette as he surveys Tony.  37 45. ANDES (CONT’D) Tell you what. If we take you back to the house where we picked you up from could you back track from there?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I could try.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Okay then, you try. Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: INT. POLICE CAR, WEST TEXAS HIGHWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: The man in uniform drives fast. Clearly used to driving l a cop. No one speaks. Bobby Andes is sitting in the passe seat and Tony in the back. The loudspeaker chatters with radio police voices. Bobby turns the sound down.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: It’s my understanding that these fellas didn’t have any guns. Tony looks down.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No. Andes stares at Tony for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Alright. Let’s get some things straight. You say this fella named Lou drove you into the brush and left you there?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: He made me drive.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: And when you started to walk out you saw them coming in again.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Which car was it?  46.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I think it was my car.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: The look of it. The sound of it. It sounded like my car.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Could you see them in the dark?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Not very well.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: What did they say?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: They said, “Mister, your wife wants you”.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you go to them? Tony looks down at his lap.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t know why I didn’t go.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Do you think they were with them? They drive by an old red billboard, glowing brightly in t harsh sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I didn’t think so then. I thought if they were she would have called out. I don’t know why I didn’t go. Something held me back.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Well, I think we had better find that road, don’t you?  38 47. They drive for quite a while and then stop in front of th small adobe house just off the highway where Tony was pic up. Bobby Andes lights a cigarette. ANDES (CONT’D) Okay. Can you take it from here?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I came down the highway. I walked for a long time. No one stopped for me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Sargent, back up slowly down the shoulder. Put your signal lights on. They move against the traffic for only a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Stop the car! Stop the car! I came out of that barbed wire fence. Right there, next to the reflector. I remember that. The officer stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Let’s get out and walk. You said you walked out here, right?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HIGHWAY, WEST TEXAS. DAY
dialogues.text: The men get out of the car and crawl under the barbed wir fence. Tony surveys the desert landscape. Bobby puts out cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I came up this way because I walked along in that arroyo over there.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: This is part of the old Valdes place. There’s a cattle station down that way a bit next to where they burn their garbage. This road leads to it.  39 40 48. INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BEDROOM. MORNING -- 39 CONTINUOUS. Susan is in her bed reading and is clearly engrossed. She nervously fondling the gold cross around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: LATER.
dialogues.text: Tony is standing stunned. His eyes are wet. In the distan there is a three sided concrete pen filled with what is l of burned garbage. In the middle of the garbage is a char and_ ripped red velvet sofa that someone has thrown out. on the sofa we see what seems to be a pair of naked lover intertwined. They do not move. Their white skin gleams in hot sun. Tony begins to move slowly towards the lovers and lowers himself to his knees in front of them. The two of them look small. Like children. White and nake the bright daylight. Bobby lifts the girl’s head gently i his hand. Tony sees her face from the side, her long red tangled in the blood across her mouth. Tony is in shock and can’t speak. Bobby lowers India’s he carefully back onto the arm of the sofa and climbs over slowly to the other side. He pushes the other body back gently by the shoulders. Tony stares at the dark red hair He sees Laura’s mouth open like she is crying out, her ch and eyes contorted with pain. Bobby Andes holds her head for him to see. Her small gold cross dangles from her nec and catches the sun.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Is this your wife?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Is she all right? The woman's face is white. The eyes fixed. Bobby does not answer.  4l 42 43

INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BEDROOM. MORNING -- 41 CONTINUOUS. Susan gasps as she continues to fondle the gold cross aro her neck. She closes the book. Her breathing is rapid and slowly collects herself. Susan picks up the phone on her night table and dials.

dialogues.speaker: -- CONTINUOUS.
dialogues.text: SAMANTHA MORROW, 16, pale white skin and long red hair is lying naked on a bed. The white arm of a boy is draped ac her. They are still. Sam’s phone rings and she turns to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Mom? Is that you? Is everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I just wanted to hear your voice. I miss you. A rustling sound as Sam drops the phone and then picks it again. We hear movement in the background and a muffled whisper.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You woke me up. I’m still in bed. It’s Sunday morning mom. Can I call you later?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m sorry sweetheart. Go back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You sound weird. Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'm fine. It’s nothing. Go back to bed sweetheart. (Pause) I love you.  44 50.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. Me too. I’1l call you later. Susan hangs up. She stares ahead but can only see the ima of Tony kneeling in front of the bodies on the sofa. She closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING.
dialogues.text: Susan at 22 is coming out of the door of Bergdorf’s and t to walk uptown. There is a young man lingering in the nex doorway watching her. He steps out just ahead of her and walks in the same direction she is walking. He walks slow than she does and they are now only a few feet apart. She realizes that she knows him, or thinks she knows him. She quickens her pace.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Edward? Edward! Edward turns around. He is handsome, beautiful in a boyis way. It is striking how much Edward looks like Tony from “Nocturnal Animals” although he has lighter hair, is youn and clean shaven. It is beginning to snow and starting to dark.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Susan! God it’s good to see someone I know. He looks her up and down.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You look beautiful. As always. They kiss on the cheek. As they do, Edward pulls her clos We see him breathe in deeply and close his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What are you doing in New York?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I am here for a scholarship interview at Columbia.  45 51.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Columbia? I thought that you were at the University of Texas, becoming a great writer.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I am. Becoming a great writer? I don’t know. Are you still at Yale becoming a great artist?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Columbia graduate school. Art History. They look silently at each other for a moment. SUSAN (CONT’D) Do you know anyone here?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Just you.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Would you like to have dinner?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Walk me home and I’11l drop these off. Edward takes her shopping bags. SUSAN (CONT’D) Thank you. I miss Texas men.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING.
dialogues.text: Susan and Edward are finished with dinner and are having drinks. It is clear that they have already had a few as t atmosphere between them is warm and intimate.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You know, you were my first crush when we were at Hastings. I really only spent so much time with your brother to be around you.  52.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: And you were his first crush.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: What? I had no idea Cooper was gay.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I don’t think he did either. Then. But he was obsessed with you. If I hadn't caught you looking at me all the time I would have thought the two of you were sleeping together.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I feel terrible that I haven’t spoken to him in a few years. I haven't been a very good friend. I hope that I didn’t hurt him.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You’re good you know. Most guys would be freaked out to find out that their best friend had been in love with them. Call him, he’d like that. My parents have basically disowned him. They don’t really speak anymore.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? You know my parents. Religious, conservative, sexist, racist, materialistic, Republican, narcissistic.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: What do you really think Susan?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It’s true. They’re pretty narrow. They look at us as just an extension of themselves. They can’t accept Cooper for who he is. I’m not sure how I will fare.  53.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Aren’t you being a little hard on them?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No. I don’t think so. They have a pretty antiquated idea about how I am supposed to live my life. My mother especially.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I’ve always loved your mother. She was great with me when my father died. Edward looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You both have the same kind of sadness in your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You and your mother.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What a weird thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I hope that doesn’t offend you. But she has always seemed sad to me. She has sad eyes. I’ve thought that since I was a little boy. You have the same eyes. They're beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Please don’t say that. I don’t want to be like my mother.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I always envied your family. I felt like a complete imposter at school.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I thought I was the only one that felt that way.  54.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I tried so hard to seem perfect.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: And you don’t feel that way?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No. Edward looks at her. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: But that’s exactly what makes you so perfect.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You'll definitely make a great novelist. You’ve created a completely fictitious character in your head.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: No. I don’t believe that. He looks into her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why did you give up on becoming an artist?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I’m too cynical to be an artist. I think to be good, you have to create from some sort of place inside that I’m not sure that I have.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You really underestimate yourself you know. Susan stares directly into Edward’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Would you come home with me?  46 55.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Wow. That’s is a bit forward. Not what I’d expect from a Texas debutante.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You know debutantes are all sluts. (Pause) And you know, you were my first crush too. Edward smiles at this.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I know. She smiles at him. He smiles back. Edward's face slowly morphs into that of Tony’s as our flashback dissolves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Edward’s smile fades in our flashback, Tony’s stunned becomes clear as he sits alone in the glass room. Bobby Andes walks into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: We got a report from Ozona. Someone else harassed on the highway last night just like you. Bobby hesitates. He puts his hand on Tony’s shoulder. ANDES (CONT’D) If you don’t mind, we’1ll need your finger prints.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Mine?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: No offense, it’s just that we found some prints on the trunk of your car.  56. Bobby pauses. ANDES (CONT’D) There’s somethin else.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: We got a cause of death. Tony slumps in his chair. ANDES (CONT’D) Your wife had a fractured skull. She appears to have been struck with a hammer, or baseball bat. Only once or twice. Your daughter had a harder time. She was suffocated. He waits for Tony to take this in. ANDES (CONT’D) She also had a broken arm. He watches Tony. He pauses. ANDES (CONT’D) And they had both been raped. Tony stares blankly ahead.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You were also right about that trailer.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: I mean your friends took your folks there just like you thought.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: How do you know that?  47 48 57.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: We found your wife’s finger prints on the bed post.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Whose trailer is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: He’s clear. Guy who lives in El Paso. The place had been broken into. Someone’s been living in it. We got other prints too in the trailer. We’ll have to check them against the owner’s and see if we can separate them out. But I’m hopeful. The owner hasn’t been there since last fall. (Pause) It looks promising. Tony looks up at Andes.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Promising? INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BEDROOM. NIGHT -- LATER. Susan lies in her bed deep in thought. FLASHBACK - INT. HIGHLAND PARK GRILL ROOM, DALLAS TEXAS. 1996 -- EVENING. Susan and her mother, ANNE SUTTON, 48, are having dinner. atmosphere at the table is tense.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me this before? Susan’s mother sits quietly fuming. She speaks calmly but there is an edge to her voice.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are actually going to leave New York and move to Austin to go to the god damned University of Texas? I thought you loved Columbia. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ANNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened to their “great art history department”? She pauses a moment. Susan, why are you doing this? I mean, where is this going to go?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean where is it going to go? I’m going to marry Edward. That’s where it’s going to go.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: This is a ridiculous conversation. You're too young to get married.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh really? Didn't you try to convince me just last summer that I should marry Bass?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: That was different. Bass is your equal.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh my god, did you just say that? You really just said that? That came out of your mouth?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Why do you always think the worst of me? That is not what I meant. What I meant is that you are very, very strong willed and as sweet as he is, Edward is just too weak for you.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Weak isn’t the word I would use to describe Edward. Sensitive is the word I would use and that’s certainly not a word that I could ever use to describe anyone in this family, except maybe Cooper.  59.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Don’t bring Cooper into this. Come on Susan. You may not think that we care about the same things but you’re wrong. In a few years, all these “bourgeois” things as you so like to call them will become very important to you. Edward won’t be able to give them to you. He has no money. He’s not driven. He’s not ambitious. And if you marry Edward, I can promise you that your father is not going to give them to you either.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No, he’s not driven in the way that you want him to be, but you’re wrong. He’s strong. Stronger than I am in a lot of ways. He just has a different kind of strength.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: A different kind of strength? And what kind of strength is that?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The strength to believe in himself. To believe in me. Anne collects herself and leans into the table.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Susan, keep seeing him if you have to. Live with him. I don’t care, but don’t marry him. I understand what you see in Edward. I get it. Susan starts to turn her head away

dialogues.speaker: ANNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No wait. I do. He’s the opposite of your father. He’s a romantic, but he’s also very fragile. I saw that when his father died.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: When did you become so compassionate and understanding.  49 60. Anne glares at her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Don’t do this. You’1ll regret it and you'll only hurt Edward in the end. What you love about him now, you'll hate about him in a few years. You may not realize it but you and I are a lot more alike than you think. Anne spots a piece of lint on Susan’s sweater. She reache forward and pulls it off. Susan watches her mother do thi and recoils slightly.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You're wrong. You and I are nothing alike.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Really? Just wait. We all eventually turn into our mothers. Anne turns away from Susan and takes a sip of her martini END FLASHBACK. INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. 49 Susan is sitting on the small sofa in her room, staring o into the LA night. She flicks open her computer, looks at the note from Edwa and types in the e-mail address. She rapidly types out a note to him but then deletes it a starts again. After a bit of deliberation she writes: Dear Edward, I am reading your book. It’s devastating. I am deeply mov It is beautifully written. I would love to meet on Tuesda evening. Let me know if you are still free. Much to say. Love, Susan She presses “send” and then snaps the computer closed.  50 51 61.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING.
dialogues.text: Tony is on his computer. He is wearing a pair of boxer sh and an old tee shirt. There is a bottle of Jack Daniels a glass next to him. He looks rough. He checks his e-mails. There is one from Bobby Andes. Tony opens the attachment and takes a deep breath. He loo at a photo of a clean shaven man. Tony looks carefully. Covers the bottom half of the face with a piece of paper. Covers the top half with a piece of paper. Tony sits at his desk with his head in his hands. His cell phone rings. He looks at the number. He doesn’t recognize it. He answers.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Tony Hastings?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes. Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Roberto Andes. I just sent you an e- mail. Did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes. I did.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Well, did you recognize the guy?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Shit. God damned it. You sure?  52 53 WE SEE TONY’S IMAGINED VERSION OF THE RAPE. BRUTAL. HIS DAUGHTER’S SCREAMS ARE PIERCING. TURK LOOKS STRAIGHT TOWARDS HIM AND SMILES. INT. HASTINGS RESIDENCE - TONY'S STUDY, HOUSTON TEXAS.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It’s like the whole thing is a blur.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: This guy’s finger prints were on your car. They were also found at the trailer. His name is Steve Adams. He has a record in California, a stolen car with an acquittal on a rape charge. We've put out an A.P.B. for him. He is our only lead right now. No one has responded to our call for witnesses. Are you sure you don’t recognize him?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Fuck. What's wrong with you man! Don’t you want these guys put away?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Of course I do! It’s all just a blank. 62. 52 CUT TO BLACK. Tony sits up in a sweat. INT. HASTINGS RESIDENCE - TONY’S BEDROOM. LATER THAT NIGH Tony lies in bed asleep, dreaming. He is tossing about an clearly in distress. IT IS VIOLENT. CUT TO BLACK.  54 55 56 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bleak hillside. Brown grass and bare trees as Tony appe over the hill in his running clothes. He has on a light jacket and long tight running pants. He is clean shaven. looks thinner. It is remarkable how he now looks almost exactly like Edward. Dark circles ring his eyes and a cer dead quality is evident in his expression. TONY V.O. I know it was him! ANDES V.O. Well, that may be but nobody’s seen him around here lately. Now listen, I’ve got to be honest with you. Right now it’s not looking good. Sometimes these cases go for months or even years without a break. You need to prepare yourself for that. Tony stops running and catches his breath. CUT TO BLACK. INT. HASTINGS RESIDENCE - TONY’S BATHROOM. EVENING. 55 Tony stands still in the shower. Just letting the hot wat run over him. INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BATHROOM. EVENING. 56 Susan is in the shower leaning against the wall, just let the water run over her face and body. She is deep in thou

dialogues.speaker: HEAD BETWEEN HIS HANDS. NO SOUND.
dialogues.text: Susan holds herself tightly while the shower steams up an the water washes over her. SUSAN V.O. Why are you so driven to write? EDWARD V.O. I guess it’s a way of keeping things alive. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Saving things that will eventually die. If I write it down, then it will last forever. Susan stands still and stares straight ahead, deep in thought. CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Andes is standing outside on the curb smoking. He i thinner and his complexion is sallow. Tony walks towards and the two men shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: You look different.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No beard. Thinner. You look different too.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
