dialogues.text: Yeah. He takes a drag off of his cigarette. ANDES (CONT’D) I’1l tell you what we've got. We have an attempted hold up of a supermarket in the mall just before closing time. We caught one fella and one got killed but one got away.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?  59 65.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: See if you recognize the fella we caught. You might also take a look at the dead one too, although it is not really necessary. We know who he is.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Steve Adams, the one that you called “Turk” and that I e-mailed you about last year. Andes takes another long drag from his cigarette and gest towards the door. ANDES (CONT’D) Come on in. He flicks his cigarette onto the pavement and turns to le Tony into the station.

dialogues.speaker: INT. POLICE STATION, WEST TEXAS. DAY
dialogues.text: Tony follows Andes down the hall. We pass a bathroom with open door and a prisoner handcuffed to the sink. Tony and Andes are now in the same glass room that Tony s in before.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Are you afraid of looking these fellas in the eyes? Lettin them see you?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Good. I think it might help this fella talk. He nods at the officer by the door. Four men are sent in. Tony stares at one of the men. The man’s eyes pass over T without recognition. Tony turns to Bobby Andes.  66.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes. (He whispers)

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes what?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That’s him. The one on the left.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s Lou. The one who made me drive into the brush and left me there. Andes motions to the officer at the door to lead the othe out. He nods at Lou to stay back. Lou begins to sweat.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: This fella? He don’t seem to understand. Lou, hey you. Is your name Lou?

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: You know my name. I told you. What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: You ever see this man before, Lou? Think carefully. You ever seen him? Lou is staring at Tony.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: No. I don’t know him. Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Tell him Tony, tell him who he is.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Last summer, this man Lou and his friends forced us off the road on the Interstate. Then two of them forced their way into my car with my wife and daughter and then this man—

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: This man here? Lou?  67.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes. Lou made me drive his car and took me into the desert where he made me get out. Later my wife and daughter were found dead at the same place. Andes now leans up against the wall and gets his face ver close to Lou’s.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: What do you say to that, Lou? What do you know about this man’s wife and daughter? Lou looks afraid.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you are talking about. I never saw him in my life.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: What do you know about Ray and Turk?

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Who? What are you an owl? Are you an owl Lou?

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: I never heard of them.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: You never heard of them?

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: No sir. Andes leans back against the wall and stares intently at Lou begins to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Officer, you can take him out. An officer leads Lou out. Tony, relieved, sits down.  68. ANDES (CONT’D) Are you sure this is the man?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Would you swear it in a court of law under penalty of perjury?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Good. We’ve got Lou now. We will charge him with Murder.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You have enough evidence?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Oh you bet. We got you and his prints on both the car and the trailer.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Then he went back to the trailer after leaving me?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Looks like it. Probably he went back and told them where he left you, and that’s why they went back with the bodies. They were going to kill you. I’m betting your friend Ray is the third guy in the holdup.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: You’1l have to come back for the trial. Meanwhile, I’m gonna find Ray.  60 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is sitting at her desk going through e-mails. Susan assistant ALEX, 26, tall and stunning enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Don’t forget you have a board meeting at the museum this afternoon at 3:00. Susan is distracted. Alex sits

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You didn’t sleep again did you? down.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You know me. I never sleep. My ex husband used to call me a “nocturnal animal”.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Your ex husband? What ex husband? I didn’t know that you had an ex husband. Since when?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: When I was in graduate school. It was only for a couple of years. It’s weird, I’ve been thinking about him a lot lately and then a few days ago he sent me a book he’s written. It’s violent and it’s sad. He called it “Nocturnal Animals” and dedicated it to me.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Did you love him?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes. I loved him. He was a writer. I didn’t have faith in him. I panicked and I did something horrible to him. Something unforgivable. Really.  61 70.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You left him?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I left him. In a brutal way, for the handsome and dashing Hutton.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Who is indeed very handsome and dashing.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Do you ever feel like your life has turned into something that you never intended? She looks at her and pauses a moment. SUSAN (CONT’D) No. Of course you don’t. You just started living your life. She looks closely at Susan.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You really didn’t get any sleep did you?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MUSEUM EXHIBITION SPACE, LOS ANGELES. THAT AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Our screen is filled with the image of a Damien Hirst cal floating in formaldehyde. The calf has been shot with arr Our camera pulls back and we see that Susan is standing staring quietly at the sculpture. The space is gigantic and white. A show is being installe There are graphic abstract paintings on the walls. As Susan turns to walk away, a painting catches her eye a she stops dead in her tracks. It is a large black and whi painting that says REVENGE. SAGE ROSS, 38, walks over to Susan. She is the museum’s director and is tense and tight in her manner. She is dre in an absurd “conceptual” top and flat men’s shoes.  71.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Where did this come from?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: What do you mean where did it come from? You bought it for us. Don’t you remember. It was part of the series we showed about 8 years ago. Great isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Sage is holding a phone with a black and white image on t screen and the loud sound of breathing coming from it.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Oh my god, it is so cool. It is an app that let’s me watch Willow while she is sleeping in her crib!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Really? Do you not trust your nanny?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: No, I do, but I hate her. And I like to be more involved with Willow during the day. Here, look. There she is in her crib. The sound is amazing. I can hear her breathe and even talk to her if I want to. Sage hands the phone to Susan, who stares at the black an white image of the little girl in her crib. As she watche she sees someone move behind the crib, and then for a qui second she sees Ray look directly into the camera. Susan gasps and drops the phone to the ground, shattering screen.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh my god, I’m so sorry.  62 63 72.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I thought I saw someone.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Of course you saw someone. It’s Willow. She’s asleep in her crib. Sage bends down to the floor and picks up the phone. It i still working and the little girl is sleeping peacefully her crib.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about the screen.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: It’s all right, the new ones come out next week. Susan is still shaken.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shall we? Everyone is waiting in the conference room. INT. MUSEUM CONFERENCE ROOM. AFTERNOON -- MINUTES LATER. We are viewing the scene from behind glass. A group of pe sit around a table. They are talking and looking over financial statements. Susan stares into space. She sits a the head of the table. She is deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MUSEUM CONFERENCE ROOM. AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Our camera moves into the room.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Anyway, I think we have to cut her loose. She’s not what she sold herself as when we hired her.  73. Another member of the group LINDA ADDISON, 50 speaks up. breasts are oddly oversized and squeezed into a tiny top.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I disagree. I think we should keep her for now.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Because she’s great. Because we all like her. She just needs our support. And a bit of time. SAMANTHA VAN HELSING, 45, interrupts Linda. Her face fill our screen. She is stretched and pulled to the extreme. H lips are swollen and her general appearance is close to t of a burn victim.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: But it’s not working. We need to fire her. There’s an awesome candidate that we could steal from the Hammer if we move fast. Susan is all of a sudden alert.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I agree with Linda. We hired her and we need to support her. The room is surprised by Susan’s response. Susan looks at Samantha. She is taken a back and looks at almost as though she has never seen her before. SUSAN (CONT’D) New doctor? Samantha glares at her.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: No. New haircut.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: But Susan, you were the one who brought this up last week. You wanted to make a change.  64 65 74.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Well, now I think we should keep her. She looks at Samantha’s swollen lips. SUSAN (CONT’D) Sometimes maybe it’s not a good idea to change things quite so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan walks into the house. Dead silence. She places her in the entry hall. She stares out at the lawn. It is dusk the city lights are just becoming visible through the mis The large plinth that held the Koons is now empty and the lawn cleaned up. She walks through the living room which now immaculate but bare. Susan pours herself a drink. The white Calder moves in the breeze from the air conditioner Susan is alone. She walks to the window with her drink in her hand and st out across the lights of Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby and Tony stand outside of Tony’s car on a dirt road Bobby is smoking a cigarette. He looks drawn and gaunt. H eyes are bloodshot and his skin is grey.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t get it. Why are we here?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Shit. Andes begins to cough, places his hand over his mouth and then buckles over for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m fine. Follow me.  66 75. EXT. RAY’S MOBILE HOME. AFTERNOON -- CONTINUOUS. 66 The two men walk through the scruffy trees until they can a mobile home and an old wooden deck about a hundred feet away. Ray is sitting on a toilet that has been installed outside on the deck. There is a beer beside him. He is shirtless, his pants are down around his ankles and he is a cordless phone smoking a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: His name is Ray Marcus and someone named him as a frequent companion of Lou Bates and Steve Adams. Tony stares harder. Clearly agitated. ANDES (CONT’D) Part time electrician. Part time plumber hence the clever toilet facilities. Not a bad match to both your description and the fella in the holdup. No fingerprints but we knew that before.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I wonder why there aren’t any finger prints.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: His hands were probably on your wife. Tony winces. ANDES (CONT’D) His record is clean except for a rape charge that was dropped. I got out of the barman at a place called “Line Camp Bar” that he lives here with a girl called Leila and that he keeps another place to pick up women that she doesn’t know about. Probably your murder trailer before it got notorious. Does he look like he could be the guy?  76.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Good. Let’s go talk to him. Andes walks out of the brush.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Ray. Ray looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What the fuck man! Who the hell are you. Get off my property. Ray speaks into the phone and then hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1l call you back.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: I want to ask you some questions.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Fuck you. I’m occupied at the moment. Bobby Andes holds up a plastic case with a badge in the window. His other hand is in his jacket. Ray squints.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: A few questions, that’s all. We need you to come with us.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What for? I ain’t done nothin.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Didn't say you did.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Ask me here.  67 77.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Naw. We need you to take a little drive with us. Finish what you’re doin and let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You mind turnin around?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Believe me I wish I could but I just can’t do that. Andes tosses Ray’s shirt to him from the back of a chair. ANDES (CONT’D) Come on. Get dressed. INT. TONY’S CAR, WEST TEXAS. AFTERNOON -- MINUTES LATER. Andes is in the back seat with Ray. Tony is in the driver seat. Andes directs Tony where to drive.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Hey, are you questioning me?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Why yes, that’s what we’re doing ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You ain’t read me my rights.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: You know your rights, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to read ‘um to me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: I read you your rights, didn’t I Tony? Tony is stunned at being brought into the game of cat and mouse.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: This ain’t legal man. I’m supposed to have a lawyer.  78.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Calm down sunshine. This is just informal questioning. That's all. You're helping me out. I haven’t charged you with anything yet. If you want a lawyer we'll have to take you in and charge you with somethin. Ray looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Aw come on man, you don’t need to take me in. I’m answering questions, ain’t I?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Well I don’t know. Seems like I don’t know no more about that holdup than I knew before. Tell you what. There’s somthin else I'd like to ask you about. You recognize this car?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What car? Andes bangs his fist against the headliner of the car.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: This car. The one we’re in. Tony takes a deep breath. Closes his eyes for a second.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: This car? Why should I recognize this fucking car?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: It ain’t familiar to you? It don’t remind you of nothin? Take you back?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: No man. Why should it? It may be taking me somewhere but damned if I know where.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don’t remember driving it?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: How about the driver? Tony’s heart begins to pound.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: The guy driving. My friend Tony here. You remember him?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I can’t see him. Make him turn around.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Stop the car, Tony. 79. Tony slows and stops on the dusty road. He feels the heav thumping of his heart. ANDES (CONT’D) Turn around and look at this piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Who is this guy?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: You don’t remember him?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Can’t say I do.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: You remember him, Tony?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes.  80.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Refresh his memory.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Last summer on the Interstate. Ray looks at him, staring. Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Tell him what you remember he did. Tony looks directly at Ray.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You killed my wife and my daughter. His voice is trembling. Ray’s eyes enlarge.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You're crazy man. I never killed nobody.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Tell him the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You and your buddies on the Interstate. You forced us off the road. His voice is quivering and his eyes are filling with wate

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Tell him who his buddies were.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Lou and Turk.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Remember that Ray? Remember horsing around on the Interstate?, Playing chicken with other cars? Ray’s voice is very soft.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You’re crazy man. That’s crazy.  81.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You made us stop and we had a flat tire. Lou and Turk fixed it. Then you and Turk got into my car with my wife and daughter and forced me into your car with Lou.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: What then Tony?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Lou took me out into the brush and kicked me out. Then you came back in my car. You called me and tried to lure me into a trap. You went to where Lou had left me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: What did you go back there for Ray?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You're fucking crazy man.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Tell him what we found there Tony.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You tell him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Do I need to? Don’t you know Ray?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You’re crazy man. I don’t know what the hell you are talking about.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: The bodies of my wife and child, which you took back there and dumped. A slight smile on Ray’s face. Almost imperceptible.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're the one. I know you. While this conversation has been going on, Andes has slip the gun out of his pocket and is holding it in his lap pointing toward Ray.  82.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Whaddaya say Ray?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You're crazy man. Andes points the gun at Ray.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're making a big mistake man.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: I don’t think so Ray. Put your arms out slowly. Andes slaps a pair of hand cuffs around Ray’s wrists.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You ain’t got no right.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Speaking of rights, I want you to know that I’m recording this conversation. He holds up a small recorder. ANDES (CONT’D) There. All clear?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: We're going back to a place you may remember. You can help by telling me about it. If you don’t remember, Tony does. He looks towards Tony. Tony pulls back onto the dirt road

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry you lost your folks man, it’s a shame. But I didn't have nothing to do with it. They pass the old adobe church. They drive until the trai is in sight just ahead. Tony stops the car in the turnout  68 83.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s this place?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You know this place. Ray looks at Tony with a deep long stare.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Honest to God, I don’t. Ray has a slight smile on his face as Tony turns and star at him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Wanna get out Tony? Andes opens his door. ANDES (CONT’D) Care to look inside Ray?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Let's just take a look. They get out of the car. Tony lags behind.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAILER, WEST TEXAS. AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Bobby Andes kicks the door open and shoves Ray inside. Th walls are blank and weathered. There is a small stove and fire tools by the door and a bed with metal bedposts and trash box full of old newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Raped them on the bed I presume.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I never raped nobody.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Come on Ray, we got your record. We know about that girl in Lubbock.  69 70 84.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Fuck that. The charges were dropped man. I ain’t never raped nobody. Tony stands in front of Ray next to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I want to know Ray, the exact story of what you did to them.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You’1l have to ask somebody else man.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I want to know what they said. I want to know what my wife said and what my daughter said. Tony stares at Ray in silence.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to know how you killed them. I want to know if they knew what was happening to them. I want to know if they hurt. I want to know what they felt. Answer me, you fucking bastard! Shot of Ray’s eyes, his teeth. A slight grin through the fear. A condescension. Tony pulls his arm back and before he knows it, with all might punches Ray in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is startled away from the book by the sound of the flaring up in the fireplace. She is lying on the sofa rea and looks up and stares at the flames. FLASHBACK - INT. EDWARD AND SUSAN’S APARTMENT, AUSTIN 199 -- NIGHT. A white brick fireplace holds a dying fire. Susan is lyin a red velvet sofa reading loose printed pages. She is concentrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it better? Susan looks up slowly. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You'll take this the wrong way but I think that you need to stop writing about yourself.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: But no one ever writes about anything but themselves. Edward looks down at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I know. But I don’t know what else to say. My mind started to wander while I was reading which is not a good thing. Edward is clearly devastated.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Maybe I need a break from it.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Maybe you do.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to do. Maybe I don’t have a book in me.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Get some space from it.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Please don’t start that again. It makes me feel like you don’t believe in me.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I didn’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: No, but your face says it. Your little “sighs” say it. The way you keep telling me that I should go back to school says it. 85.  86.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I do think you should go back to school. I think you need to be realistic. I mean come on, you’re really smart. A part time job ina book store and writing a novel is a romantic idea but is this really our life? Is this what it’s going to be? For how long?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You sound just like your mother.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Well, you always said I was so like her. That’s why I hate reading your work. You always get so fucking defensive about it.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Of course I’m defensive. Do you know what it’s like to put yourself out on a limb creatively and then to have someone you love read what you've written and not understand it?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No, I don’t because I’m not creative, Edward.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: That’s because you’ve chosen not to be! She glares at him. EDWARD (CONT’D) I don’t want to fight. I’m tired and I’m edgy and I’ve been writing all night. I just wanted you to like it. END FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The book slides from Susan’s lap to the ground. She sits and collects herself. She bends down to pick the book up.  72 73 87.

dialogues.speaker: TEXAS AT AUSTIN. 1997
dialogues.text: Susan’s book falls to the ground. She bends to pick it up she sits in the back of a class listening to a professor. The sound of a slide projector clicks over and over. The light from the screen flashes on Susan’s face. We are aware of someone staring at her. She becomes aware it too and turns to see Hutton at 24, very clean cut and preppy staring at her. Their eyes lock for a moment but s quickly looks away. He keeps staring.

dialogues.speaker: END FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: EXT. ANDES’S CAMP, WEST TEXAS. DAY. 73 Bobby is leaning against his truck in the hot mid day sun talking on the phone to Tony.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: I’ve got some news you won’t like. They're letting Ray Marcus go.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What! What do you mean they’re letting him go?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: The DA says there is not enough hard evidence and that the evidence that there is, is circumstantial. He needs corroboration. Tony is silent. ANDES (CONT’D) I’m real sorry Tony. It’s a god damned shame. At least you got to lay a good belt on him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No, that’s not enough. What else can we do? Andes takes a deep drag from his cigarette.  74 88.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: I‘1l think of something. Get here as fast as you can. He won’t stick around long.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’1l leave now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Andes sit in a booth by the window directly oppo where their cars are parked. Their dinners are on their plates.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: I told you. I’ve got lung cancer. It’s metastasized.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: But you smoke all the time.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Yep. That’s how it works. What’s the point of quitting now? I'll be dead in a year. Tony looks at Andes. ANDES (CONT’D) It’s this fella called Jenks. He’s the lawyer that the court appointed. Smart ass from Dallas. He and the DA made a deal and Ray gets off. Politics.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: When did you tell me that you were sick?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: They want to push me out. They have someone else they want to put in the job.  89.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t understand what you are talking about. Would they drop a murder case to do that?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Gives them the reason. They said the case wasn’t well prepared, was a sloppy job, slapdash, no evidence, evidence gathered improperly, won’t stand up in court. The DA is too much of a chicken shit to take on a case that he might loose. Tony mulls this over. ANDES (CONT’D) They're not dropping Lou.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It’s no fucking good if they don’t get Ray.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Good. That's what I was hoping you'd say. They think it’s time I retired and enjoyed the benefits of my cancer somewhere else. Fuck that.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You never told me about the cancer. Do you have a family?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: The problem with Ray is his Alibi.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Stop it. Do you have anyone in your life?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: No. No wife. I have a daughter in Corpus.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Has she been a help?  90.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: She doesn’t know. What can she do about it? Tony looks at Bobby for a moment and Bobby looks him in t eye, then turns back to his plate. ANDES (CONT’D) Anyway Ray claims that he was with Leila whatever her name is and she backs him up, and her aunt backs her up.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So what are we going to do? He looks at Tony for a long time which makes Tony nervous

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: It’s a question of how serious you are about seeing justice done. You get me? Bobby can’t eat his food. ANDES (CONT’D) Can’t eat. Might throw up.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: How do you get along if you can’t eat?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: It depends. Sometimes I can eat, sometimes I can’t. This place sucks.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I need you to eat something. Bobby takes a breath and tries to keep his food down.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Let me ask you a personal question. Between us, okay? What do you want me to do with Ray Marcus.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What can you do to him?  75 76 91.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Anything you god damn like.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I thought you said- Andes coughs.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Look, I’ve got nothin to loose, and I can’t let this ass-hole DA fuck up my last case. I also can’t stand by and watch a murderer go free. I’ve watched too many sick fucks like Ray Marcus get off over the years. Are you willing to go outside of strict procedure on this?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes. Andes's cell phone rings. He answers.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Ray is at “Line Camp”. I’m going to let that little idiot get nice and liquored up and then I’m going to go grab his ass and take him out to my camp. I want you to come too. I want to keep him with us a while. Work him over a bit. Get a little rough, make him suffer a little. See what he does. Would you like that?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yes. INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. 75 Susan looks up from the book and leans her head back in thought.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Edward and Susan are walking down the street. They are arguing.  She looks 92.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Edward, you have to realize this is not working. We’re not right for each other, I wish we were, but we're just not.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: What do you mean, we’re not right for each other? We’re perfect for each other.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No Edward. We're not. We might be perfect for each other if we didn’t live in the real world. I need a life that is more structured and I need a future that is more structured. I want to be the person that you want me to be but I just can’t.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: But you are, you are. Just stop.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I really wanted to be this person that you thought I was. I really did, but I’m just not that person. I just don’t have your kind of faith in things. I’m cynical, I’m pragmatic. I’m a realist.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: No, you're just afraid. We have been through this so many times.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: No, I’m not scared Edward. I’m unhappy. I’m just really, really unhappy. at him. Edward is shaken. SUSAN (CONT’D) We're different and we want different things. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUSAN (CONT’D) You're wonderful and romantic, and sweet and sensitive, and all the things I’m not. Life for you is a kind of a dream.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Weak. I’m weak. That’s what you want to say. Go ahead and say it. You've said it before. Weak.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I did not say that you were weak! I said sensitive, and romantic.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Do you still love me?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: That is not the point. He turns and holds her by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: It is the point. You didn’t answer me.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Well when you love someone you work things out. You don’t just throw it away. You have to be careful with it. You might never get it back. Edward leans in and pulls her close.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I can’t do this with you any more Edward. I just can’t keep doing this. Susan pulls away and walks off. Edward stands on the sidewalk. He shouts after her.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You can’t just walk away from things all the time Susan!  77 78 79
We linger on Edward’s face which is lit by a red neon sig above an auto body shop. END FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up on Tony’s face. He is sitting in his car outside the “Line Camp Bar” The red neon sign outside of the plac casts a bright light into the car and on his face. A smal crowd is gathered outside of the entrance. Two obese wome shorts sit in lawn chairs drinking beer. One woman has he beer between her breasts and she is wearing a paper crown from a fast food restaurant. After a while two men come out. Ray and Andes. They talk the glow of the sign. Two policemen appear at the door. A gestures and one of the policemen touches Ray’s shoulder. recoils then submits as the other policeman puts him in handcuffs and leads him over to the police car. Bobby And comes over to Tony’s car window.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: We're going to my camp. It’s in White Creek near the trailer where they took your folks. You follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull in under a cluster of mesquite trees. They all out and Tony follows them in. The cabin is a simple structure of weathered white clapbo with a front screened-in porch.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ANDES CAMP, WEST TEXAS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: They enter through the screen door. Bobby Andes has a gun his hand. Ray is handcuffed. The room has a table, a cot, and a few old chairs. There an alcove with a sink and an open door to a bedroom. The policemen get into their car and pull away. Andes kicks Ray onto the cot.  95.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Sit up. Ray looks up at him. ANDES (CONT’D) Jesus, I feel sick. I'll be right back. Andes looks ill. He shoves the gun at Tony. ANDES (CONT’D) Here. Use it. Shoot him if he get’s out of line. We hear Andes throwing up. Ray laughs a bit to himself at this. Bobby comes back in.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Hey man. This ain’t legal. If this was legal you’d of taken me to the station, not this fucking place. Bobby takes the gun from Tony and cocks it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: It’s all the legal we need boy. Andes turns and spits on Ray as he walks around him to si down. Ray winces and tosses his head back in an attempt t get the spit off of his face.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You lied to me. There ain’t no new evidence. Why don’t you take me in if you got new evidence.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: I like it better here. It’s more relaxed. Ray motions to Tony.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Seems to me that you tried this trick already. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you think this guy is going to break me down, you’ve already seen that don’t work.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: What would you say Ray, if your friend Lou Bates implicated you in the Hastings murders?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: If Lou had done that you would have taken me in.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: We'll get you to the station. Don’t worry. Just then we hear another car pull up. Light through the window. Male voices. Lou comes in followed by an officer his gun. Lou looks at the three men.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. Bobby gestures to Lou to sit next to Ray on the cot.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey Lou. What did you tell this guy.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: I didn’t tell him anything.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: He said you told him that I was the one that killed this guy’s wife and kid.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Shit man. That’s what he told me about you. Lou looks at Bobby. Outraged.

dialogues.speaker: LOU, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to be the law man. What kind of bull shit is this?  97.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Fuck off. You two got anything to say to each other? He slumps down.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You okay Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: I’m thinking of just killing them now. You see, if I let them go, it’ll be rough on these poor guys, not knowing how it will come. The police are all around. Ray could get killed resisting arrest for example. Or coming home to his house late at night he could get shot by a burglar. Andes taunts Ray by holding the gun near his head. Lou is pulling at his handcuffs. ANDES (CONT’D) Feeling uncomfortable boy? He goes over and presses his gun in Lou’s neck. As he doe this he pulls Lou up by the shirt collar. ANDES (CONT’D) Yea, you look like you're feeling uncomfortable. Andes presses the gun harder into Lou’s neck.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: What’s that? Don’t worry. I’m not going to kill you son. I’m a police man. Lou begins to break down. ANDES (CONT’D) What? Are you going to cry? Well then, since you're feeling so uncomfortable...  98. He gestures to Tony and hands him his gun. He turns Lou directly to Tony. ANDES (CONT’D) Come on Tony. Right here. Here he is. While Tony is holding the gun on Lou, Andes unlock’s his handcuffs.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What about me? I might be feeling uncomfortable too.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Okay. Come on up. I’1l undo your cuffs. Andes undoes Ray’s cuffs. ANDES (CONT’D) There you go. Free as a bird! Okay? How about it? He shoves them towards Tony who is nervously holding the ANDES (CONT’D) What do you say Tony? Now what should we do with these two? He looks directly at Tony. ANDES (CONT’D) What are you going to do? What are you going to do son? Come on. Come on. Bobby once again buckles over in pain and rushes to the b room. We hear him being sick. Tony continues to hold the nervously.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Fuck this. Let’s go Lou.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: What? He’s got a gun.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Come on you jackass it’s time to go.  80 81 82 99. Tony tries to cock the gun and block Ray from the door. I the shadow of the bedroom he sees Bobby coming back into room.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Shoot him Tony! Ray moves towards him as Tony panics, hesitates and moves aside. When Lou sees this he starts off too and both men for the door. Andes rushes into the room and grabs the gun from Tony as men rush out the door. Andes follows. There is a shot. Then two more. Lou lies wounded on the p and Andes stands with the gun in his hand as Ray escapes the desert. Transfixed, Andes walks over to Lou and shoots him in the head. We hear a loud pop. INT. MORROW HOUSE - SUSAN’S BEDROOM. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS. There is a loud pop on the large plate glass window. Susan is startled. As she walks over to the window she se that a bird has flown into the glass and is lying outside flapping its wings. Susan stands for a moment watching as bird dies. Its wings flapping more and more slowly until stop.

dialogues.speaker: DAY.
dialogues.text: Rain pounds on the window. Hutton helps Susan on with her coat. A nurse can be seen walking away from them.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL CLINIC, AUSTIN TEXAS, 1997. DAY
dialogues.text: It is raining. The windshield wipers are on. Both Hutton Susan are wet. Hutton is sitting in the driver’s seat. Su is in the passenger seat.  100.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'll live to regret this. I regret it now. Susan shakes her head. She is staring down at her knees. is fingering the small gold cross at her neck. SUSAN (CONT’D) You know, I don’t even believe in abortions. I’m Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, Susan. I feel useless.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You're anything but useless. You always seem to know exactly what to do. Thank you. Hutton reaches across and clenches Susan’s hand. SUSAN (CONT’D) I don’t think I can ever look at Edward again. It would kill him to know that I’ve done this to his child. It’s killing me. Susan begins to cry. Hutton reaches across and holds her.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: He’s never going to know about it. Susan is sobbing now and is trembling.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What have I done? Hutton leans over and holds Susan tight as she cries.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTON
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I promise it will be okay. I’1l make it okay. As the windshield wipers flick the water off of the windshield we see that there is a man standing next to hi car in the rain across the parking lot. It’s Edward.  83 101. As Susan looks up, she sees Edward staring directly at he

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh my god no. Edward. Our camera lingers on Edward's face. END FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ANDES CABIN, WEST TEXAS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Our camera is on Tony’s face as he stares down at Lou’s b He stands still, seemingly in a trance. Andes walks over him. Tony places his hands up to his face as he begins to breathe erratically. The sounds coming from deep within h body are guttural and animal-like as he cries out. His sobbing becomes hysterical. Out of control. He is gasping alr.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Tony. You know I had to shoot him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t give a god damned fuck that you shot him! I’m glad that you shot him! I’m glad that he’s dead! I should have done it when I had the chance. I should have protected them! I should have seen it coming! I should have stopped it! I should have stopped it. Tony drops down onto his knees. Andes kneels down and put his arm around Tony who continues to sob uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: It’s okay, it’s okay. You're okay.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I should have stopped it Bobby!

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: Look at me. You’re okay. You’re a good man. Tony sits still and slowly catches his breath. His face i wet with tears.  84 85 102. ANDES (CONT’D) Come on. Get up. We have to go. If Ray gets to the road he’1l hitchhike. We need to catch him before he gets a ride. When you get to the fork in the road turn left. That goes back towards where he took your folks. He might hide there although I doubt it. I suspect he’s headed towards the highway. I'll go that way. He hands Tony a gun. ANDES (CONT’D) Here. Take this. I have another one in the car.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Are you in trouble for all of this?

dialogues.speaker: ANDES
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I don’t give a shit. I'm dying, remember? He watches Andes get into his car and start it up. As Ton backs out his headlights rake across the body lying in th dirt. INT. TONY’S CAR, DIRT ROAD, WEST TEXAS. NIGHT -- LATER. 8 Tony drives down the dark road. As his lights illuminate brush on either side of the road we see the trailer ahead Tony slows down for a moment and stares at the trailer. I dark, unlit. After a few minutes he stops the car and thi He turns off his lights and backs the car slowly down the road and eases it into a small clearing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DIRT ROAD, WEST TEXAS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Tony quietly gets out of the car and slowly starts toward the trailer. He silently slips up the steps and inside th unlocked door.  86 103.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAILER, WEST TEXAS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: In a sudden move he pushes the door open. There on the be Ray, who sits up on his elbows shocked. Tony points the g directly at him.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Christ. You. Where’s your pal?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: He’s on his way.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Your cop friends?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: They’re around.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Are they here? Ray sits up and looks out of the window. Tony flicks on t light.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Just me for the moment.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You and that fucking gun that you don’t know how to use. What happened to Lou?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: He’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What? That son of a bitch killed him! That’s big trouble for your friend, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Oh you don’t think so? And so just what do you want. You and that silly gun. I’ve seen how handy you are with that thing. Ray stands up. Tony cocks the gun.  104.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Sit the fuck down! Sit down or I will fucking kill you! Ray is stunned by the tone of Tony’s voice and backs up t the bed and sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Listen man. Why does a nice guy like you hang out with a guy like Andes. He kills people.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You kill people. Ray looks at Tony in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: They had it coming to them. Your fuckin wife. That kid. Tony is livid. He is invigorated.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you got me wrong man. It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Accident! It was an accident!

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I got a certain pride in how people talk to me and there are certain things I don’t put up with. Let me tell you man, when someone accuses me of something, that’s an insult. It gives me the right. If my woman accuses me of fucking somebody else, then I go fuck somebody else. If your fucking daughter thinks I’m a rapist, then she gets raped. Tony is livid.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nobody gets away with what you did. Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: They don’t?  105. Tony is pointing the gun directly at Ray and closes his e for a moment as he squeezes the handle of the gun. He is almost in a trance.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Nobody. Nobody. Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: So why don’t you just kill me? Come on man, you don’t know nothin. It’s fun to kill people. You of all people ought to try it sometime. Ray is quietly sliding his hand under the pillow on the b He has hidden a metal rod of some kind there and we see h fingers slide around the handle.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Fun! Did you have fun killing my wife and daughter! Get up. It’s time for you to go.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go. Go on. Ray surveys Tony and the room. He stands up slowly. One h is holding the fire poker behind his back. Ray looks Tony in the face. He begins to grin.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Your wife. Yeah, I remember your fuckin wife. I remember fuckin your wife, but you’re too weak. To fuckin weak. You’re too weak to do anything about it. Tony pulls the trigger and the gun goes off. It misses Ra

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch! Tony pulls the trigger again. Ray is hit and grabs at his chest but is now moving towards Tony with the fire poker his hand. He swings it towards Tony’s face as our screen dark. Absolute silence. CUT TO BLACK.  87 88 89 106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our sound returns as we hear flies buzzing close by. Our screen is black but begins to shift to a warm brown as mu daylight starts to illuminate the image. Tony is lying on the floor of the trailer. His head is covered in blood that has began to crust over. As a fly crawls across his face he slowly reaches up in pain to fa away. We see that there is a bloody gash across his face. eyes are covered in dried blood and as he claws at them w realize that he has been blinded. Tony realizes this too. He feels around and finds the gun. He holds onto it and f a chair and pulls himself up. Light is now pouring into t room. He manages to get to his feet. As he begins to stumble around the room he walks into something. Someone. It is Ray. He is dead and lying in a of blood. Tony bends down and runs his hands over Ray’s face and li the deadweight of the arm. He still holds the fire poker one hand. Tony finds his way out of the trailer. As he does he fall the ground.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRAILER, WEST TEXAS. DAY
dialogues.text: He drags himself into the brush and towards the road. He struggles to reach into the air and fires the gun then dr to the ground. He tries to lift the gun back up in the air in an attempt fire it once again. As he rises to his knees he falls bac the ground and onto the gun. A loud gunshot. He has shot himself in the stomach. He is still alive but begins to loose consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is in her tub. Her face is completely submerged. He eyes are open. She suddenly sits up and gasps for air.  90 91 92 107.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRAILER, WEST TEXAS. DAY
dialogues.text: Our camera slides up Tony’s body to see him grasp at his for the small _ gold cross. A breeze causes a loud brushing sound of the grass in the wind as the sound of the insects rises. The sound of Tony’s heartbeat becomes louder and louder a overtakes all other sound as our camera settles on his fa With each beat we cut back and forth from his face, to th of Susan’s as she begins to cry. The sounds of Tony’s cries of pain mingle with Susan’s cr TONY’S FACE. SUSAN'S FACE. TONY’S FACE. SUSAN’S FACE, UNT SUDDENLY TONY'S HEARTBEAT STOPS. INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BATHROOM. NIGHT -- 91 CONTINUOUS. Susan is in tears as she grabs at the gold cross around h neck.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (Softly) Edward. CUT TO BLACK. INT. MORROW RESIDENCE - SUSAN’S BEDROOM. NIGHT -- LATER. The lights are out. Susan is lying in bed wide awake thinking. Her eyes are still wet. Her thoughts are interrupted by the buzz of an e-mail on her phone. She reaches over to the bedside table and opens the message. Dear Susan, Just let me know when and where. Edward. A soft smile comes over Susan’s face as she quickly types a response.  93 94 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan stands in front of her bathroom mirror. She is dres to go out. She raises her face slightly and looks at hers intently. She reaches for a tissue and wipes the lipstick of her mouth. She begins to put her wedding ring back on her finger but stops for a moment and looks at her hand. She slips the r back into the tray on her dressing table.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RESTAURANT, LOS ANGELES. EVENING
dialogues.text: Susan walks into the restaurant. She looks especially beautiful and somehow younger. Susan follows the hostess to a table overlooking the courtyard. It is dusk and the lights of the city below ar beginning to glisten. It is a beautiful LA night.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: May I get you a drink while you wait? She smiles at the hostess.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you. Scotch on the rocks. Susan is seated next to a young couple who are leaning in closely to each other. Time passes. Lingering shots of Susan. Her hands as she f the finger where her wedding ring usually rests. Her legs they cross and uncross. Long shot of her sitting by herse in a room full of people looking back towards the entry d of the restaurant. She has finished her drink.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: Mrs. Morrow, are you all right? May I get you another drink?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you. More time passes. She finishes her second drink. The coup next to her has now left and the table is empty.  109. Long shot of Susan sitting alone in the now almost desert room. She sits still looking out over the lights of the c Susan Morrow stares straight ahead and into the night. Th expression on her face belies her realization that Edward not coming. CUT TO BLACK.
